Package org.jtrim2.stream

Class FluentSeqGroupProducer<T>

java.lang.Object
org.jtrim2.stream.FluentSeqGroupProducer<T>
Type Parameters:
T - the type of the elements to be produced
public final class FluentSeqGroupProducer<T> extends Object
Defines a convenient fluent style builder for producers producing a zero or more sequences of elements. Instances of this class can be created through the toFluent() method of SeqGroupProducer.

Mutator like methods always return a new instance and do not change the original SeqGroupProducer instance.

For simple factory methods for initial producer implementations, see the factory methods in SeqProducer or SeqGroupProducer.

Thread safety

Instances of this class are immutable, and are therefor safe to be used by multiple threads concurrently. This property does not extend to the wrapped SeqGroupProducer.

Synchronization transparency

Methods of this class are synchronization transparent, so they can be called in any context (e.g.: while holding a lock).
See Also:
  • SeqGroupProducer.toFluent()
  • FluentSeqProducer

  • Method Details

    • apply

      public <T1> FluentSeqGroupProducer<T1> apply(Function<? super SeqGroupProducer<T>,? extends SeqGroupProducer<T1>> configurer)
      Transforms the wrapped SeqGroupProducer using the given function and returns a fluent style builder for the transformation result. This method exists to allow fluent style continuation using custom transformations. For example: 
      
 builder
     .apply(SeqGroupProducer::flatteningProducer)
     // ...

      For an instance of FluentSeqProducer named builder, this method call is equivalent to configurer.apply(builder.unwrap()).toFluent().

      Type Parameters:
      T1 - the type of the elements produced by the returned producer
      Parameters:
      configurer - the transformation transforming the wrapped producer. This argument cannot be null, and the transformation cannot return null.
      Returns:
      the wrapped SeqGroupProducer transformed using the given function as fluent style builder. This method never returns null.
      See Also:
      • SeqGroupProducer.flatteningProducer

    • mapGroups

      public <R> FluentSeqGroupProducer<R> mapGroups(SeqGroupMapper<? super T,? extends R> mapper)
      Returns a producer producing the elements produced by this producer after transformed by the given mapper. Note that the mapper is not necessarily a one-to-one mapper, it might even filter or add more elements (and may not even produce the same number of sequences).
      Type Parameters:
      R - the type of the elements produced by the returned producer
      Parameters:
      mapper - the mapper mapping the elements of this producer. This argument cannot be null.
      Returns:
      a producer producing the elements produced by this producer after transformed by the given mapper. This method never returns null.

    • batch

      public FluentSeqGroupProducer<List<T>> batch(int batchSize)
      Returns a producer producing the same elements as this producer but grouped into lists of size batchSize (except for the final list, which may contain less). Note that as a side-effect, the processing steps will receive elements only after batchSize number of elements are received or when the stream processing ends. Note that each sequence is treated separately, and elements of different sequences will not be mixed in any case. Also, the returned producer will produce exactly as many sequences as this producer.

      For example, if this producer is producing a single sequence [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8], and batchSize == 0, then the returned producer will produce a single sequence. [[1, 2, 3], [4, 5, 6], [7, 8]].

      Parameters:
      batchSize - the number of elements to be collected into each (except the last one) produced list. This argument must be greater than or equal to 1.
      Returns:
      a producer grouping elements into lists of size batchSize (except the last list). This method never returns null.
      See Also:
      • SeqGroupProducer.flatteningProducer
      • FluentSeqProducer.batch

    • peekGroups

      public FluentSeqGroupProducer<T> peekGroups(SeqGroupConsumer<? super T> seqGroupPeeker)
      Returns a producer producing the same elements as this producer, but doing the given processing action before providing the element for the next processing step.
      Parameters:
      seqGroupPeeker - the consumer doing the defined action on the produced sequence. This argument cannot be null.
      Returns:
      a producer producing the same elements as this producer, but doing the given processing action before providing the element for the next processing step. This method never returns null.

    • limitEachSequence

      public FluentSeqGroupProducer<T> limitEachSequence(long maxNumberOfElements)
      Returns a producer producing the first maxNumberOfElements elements of each sequence of this producer. If this producer produces sequences shorter than or equal to maxNumberOfElements elements, then this method will do effectively nothing.

      Note: This feature relies on the fact that the exceptions are rethrown to the caller as is.

      Parameters:
      maxNumberOfElements - the maximum number of elements the returned producer supposed to produce. This argument must be greater than or equal to zero.
      Returns:
      a producer producing the first maxNumberOfElements elements of each sequence of this producer. This method never returns null.

    • toBackground

      public FluentSeqGroupProducer<T> toBackground(String executorName, int consumerThreadCount, int queueSize)
      Returns a producer resplitting the produced sequences into consumerThreadCount number of sequences and processes each sequence on a new separate thread.

      The implementation puts the produced elements into a blocking queue, and proceeds to produce further elements. Aside from the potential parallelization, the benefit is that the producer and consumer runs in parallel, but if the producer is quicker, then it won't overload the memory and be blocked once the queue is full. That is, if the producer and consumer uses different resources, then you can achieve better resource utilization. If there is no or only insignificant variance between producing or processing element, then the queueSize argument can be set to zero to retain less elements concurrently.

      Parameters:
      executorName - the name given to the executor running the processing tasks. This name will appear in the name of the executing threads. This argument cannot be null.
      consumerThreadCount - the number of threads processing elements concurrently. This argument must be greater than or equal to zero.
      queueSize - the number of extra elements to store aside from what the consumer threads are processing. That is, the threads are effectively part of the queue. So, the total outstanding elements are consumerThreadCount + queueSize. This argument must be greater than or equal to zero. Setting this argument to zero is often appropriate, but can be set to a higher value to reduce the down time due to variance in producing and processing times.
      Returns:
      a producer resplitting the produced sequences into consumerThreadCount number of sequences and processes each sequence on a new separate thread. This method never returns null.

    • toBackground

      public FluentSeqGroupProducer<T> toBackground(TaskExecutor executor, int consumerThreadCount, int queueSize)
      Returns a producer resplitting the produced sequences into consumerThreadCount number of sequences and processes each sequence in a new separate task of the given executor.

      The implementation puts the produced elements into a blocking queue, and proceeds to get further elements. Aside from the potential parallelization, the benefit is that the producer and consumer runs in parallel, but if the producer is quicker, then it won't overload the memory and be blocked once the queue is full. That is, if the producer and consumer uses different resources, then you can achieve better resource utilization. If there is no or only insignificant variance between producing or processing element, then the queueSize argument can be set to zero to retain less elements concurrently.

      Note that it is normally expected that the executor can run consumerThreadCount tasks in parallel (which will run for the whole duration of the whole processing uninterrupted), when submitted from the context where the jobs would be running otherwise. If that is not the case, then the implementation might assume that the jobs submitted to the executor will eventually start for the purpose of queue settings. However, dead-lock will only arise in case not even a single task submitted to the given executor can start running, and in that case dead-lock is a necessity.

      Parameters:
      executor - the executor running the consumer tasks. This argument cannot be null.
      consumerThreadCount - the number of threads processing elements concurrently. This argument must be greater than or equal to zero.
      queueSize - the number of extra elements to store aside from what the consumer threads are processing. That is, the threads are effectively part of the queue. So, the total outstanding elements are consumerThreadCount + queueSize. This argument must be greater than or equal to zero. Setting this argument to zero is often appropriate, but can be set to a higher value to reduce the down time due to variance in producing and processing times.
      Returns:
      a producer resplitting the produced sequences into consumerThreadCount number of sequences and processes each sequence in a new separate task of the given executor. This method never returns null

    • toBackgroundRetainSequences

      public FluentSeqGroupProducer<T> toBackgroundRetainSequences(String executorName, int queueSize)
      Returns a producer processing each sequence on a background thread while retaining the sequences of this producer. A new thread is spawned for each sequences, so the parallelization property of the returned producer will remain the same as this producer. The benefit of the returned producer is that the producers and consumers run in parallel, but if the producer is quicker, then it won't overload the memory and be blocked once the queue is full. That is, if the producer and consumer uses different resources, then you can achieve better resource utilization. If there is no or only insignificant variance between producing or processing element, then the queueSize argument can be set to zero to retain less elements concurrently.
      Parameters:
      executorName - the name given to the executor running the processing tasks. This name will appear in the name of the executing threads. This argument cannot be null.
      queueSize - the number of extra elements to store aside from what the consumer threads are processing. That is, the threads are effectively part of the queue. So, the total outstanding elements are queueSize + 1 for each sequence. Note that there is a separate queue for each sequence. This argument must be greater than or equal to zero. Setting this argument to zero is often appropriate, but can be set to a higher value to reduce the down time due to variance in producing and processing times.
      Returns:
      a producer processing each sequence on a background thread while retaining the sequences of this producer. This method never returns null.

    • toBackgroundRetainSequences

      public FluentSeqGroupProducer<T> toBackgroundRetainSequences(TaskExecutor executor, int queueSize)
      Returns a producer processing each sequence on a background task of the given executor while retaining the sequences of this producer. A new task is submitted to the given executor for each sequences, so the parallelization property of the returned producer will remain the same as this producer as long as the given executor supports that level of parallelization. The benefit of the returned producer is that the producers and consumers run in parallel, but if the producer is quicker, then it won't overload the memory and be blocked once the queue is full. That is, if the producer and consumer uses different resources, then you can achieve better resource utilization. If there is no or only insignificant variance between producing or processing element, then the queueSize argument can be set to zero to retain less elements concurrently.

      The given executor must be able to run at least a single task in the context of stream processing. Note however that if the given executor cannot run as many tasks in parallel as the number of threads used by this producer, then the processing of sequences will be serialized. That is, a task submitted to the given executor will always fully process a whole sequence of elements.

      Parameters:
      executor - the executor running the consumer tasks. This argument cannot be null.
      queueSize - the number of extra elements to store aside from what the consumer tasks are processing. That is, the tasks are effectively part of the queue. So, the total outstanding elements are queueSize + 1 for each sequence. Note that there is a separate queue for each sequence. This argument must be greater than or equal to zero. Setting this argument to zero is often appropriate, but can be set to a higher value to reduce the down time due to variance in producing and processing times.
      Returns:
      a producer processing each sequence on a background thread while retaining the sequences of this producer. This method never returns null.

    • toSynchronized

      public FluentSeqProducer<T> toSynchronized()
      Returns a FluentSeqProducer producing all elements of all sequences of this producer as a single sequence. The order within the same sequence is preserved, but there is no ordering guarantee between elements of different sequences.

      The merging is done by acquiring a lock (the same lock for each element of each sequences) while processing the element produced by this producer.

      This method is a bridge between the SeqGroupProducer and SeqProducer.

      Returns:
      a FluentSeqProducer producing all elements of all sequences of this producer as a single sequence. This method never returns null.

    • toForEachable

      public ForEachable<T> toForEachable()
      Returns a ForEachable providing the elements of this producer. Notice that ForEachable accepts a Consumer which does not declare any checked exceptions, while this API usually allows producers and consumers to throw any instance of Exception. Therefore, the returned ForEachable have to (and will) rethrow checked exceptions wrapped into a RuntimeException.

      Note: Unlike most part of this stream API, the returned ForEachable considers InterruptedException thrown by this producer. That is, when this producer throws an InterruptedException, the current thread is reinterrupted, and the exception is rethrown wrapped into a RuntimeException.

      Returns:
      a ForEachable providing the elements of this producer. This method never returns null.

      Returns an action which, when executed, produces the elements of this producer, and then consumes them with the given consumer.
      Parameters:
      seqGroupConsumer - the consumer processing the elements produced by this producer. This argument cannot be null.
      Returns:
      an action which, when executed, produces the elements of this producer, and then consumes them with the given consumer. This method never returns null.

    • withContextFreeSeqConsumer

      public CancelableTask withContextFreeSeqConsumer(SeqConsumer<? super T> seqConsumer)
      Returns an action which, when executed, produces the elements of this producer, and then consumes them with the given consumer. The same consumer is applied to each sequences independently.
      Parameters:
      seqConsumer - the consumer processing the elements produced by this producer. This argument cannot be null.
      Returns:
      an action which, when executed, produces the elements of this producer, and then consumes them with the given consumer. This method never returns null.

    • withSingleShotSeqConsumer

      public CancelableTask withSingleShotSeqConsumer(SeqConsumer<? super T> seqConsumer)
      Returns an action which, when executed, produces the elements of this producer, and then consumes them with the given consumer assuming no more than one sequence is produced by this producer. If this producer produces more than one sequences, then the processing will fail.
      Parameters:
      seqConsumer - the consumer processing the elements produced by this producer. This argument cannot be null.
      Returns:
      an action which, when executed, produces the elements of this producer, and then consumes them with the given consumer. This method never returns null.

    • withContextFreeConsumer

      public CancelableTask withContextFreeConsumer(ElementConsumer<? super T> consumer)
      Returns an action which, when executed, produces the elements of this producer, and then consumes them with the given consumer. The same consumer is applied to each element of each sequence independently.
      Parameters:
      consumer - the consumer processing the elements produced by this producer. This argument cannot be null.
      Returns:
      an action which, when executed, produces the elements of this producer, and then consumes them with the given consumer. This method never returns null.

    • withCollector

      public <R> CancelableFunction<R> withCollector(Collector<? super T,?,? extends R> collector)
      Returns an action which, when executed, processes the elements of the sequence produced by this producer the same way as the Stream.collect does.

      For example, the following code produces the list [2, 4, 6, 8]: 

      
 List<Integer> result = SeqProducer.copiedArrayProducer(1, 2, 3, 4)
     .toFluent()
     .mapContextFree(ElementMapper.oneToOneMapper(e -> 2 * e))
     .toSingleGroupProducer()
     .withCollector(Collectors.toList())
     .execute(Cancellation.UNCANCELABLE_TOKEN);
      Type Parameters:
      R - the type of result of the collection or reduction operation
      Parameters:
      collector - the collector collecting or reducing the elements of this producer. This argument cannot be null.
      Returns:
      an action which, when executed, collects and returns the elements of this producer using the given Collector. This method never returns null.

    • collect

      public <R> R collect(CancellationToken cancelToken, Collector<? super T,?,? extends R> collector) throws Exception
      Processes the elements of the sequence produced by this producer the same way as the Stream.collect does.

      For example, the following code produces the list [2, 4, 6, 8]: 

      
 List<Integer> result = SeqProducer.copiedArrayProducer(1, 2, 3, 4)
     .toFluent()
     .mapContextFree(ElementMapper.oneToOneMapper(e -> 2 * e))
     .toSingleGroupProducer()
     .collect(Cancellation.UNCANCELABLE_TOKEN, Collectors.toList());
      This method is effectively the same as calling: withCollector(collector).execute(cancelToken).
      Type Parameters:
      R - the type of result of the collection or reduction operation
      Parameters:
      cancelToken - the cancellation token which should be checked if the processing is to be canceled before completing the whole processing. There is no guarantee that the implementation will detect the cancellation request, but a best effort check will be made. If cancellation was detected by this call, then it must respond by throwing an OperationCanceledException. This argument cannot be null.
      collector - the collector collecting or reducing the elements of this producer. This argument cannot be null.
      Returns:
      the result of the collection or reduction. Normally a collector should not return null, so in that case this method will not return null.
      Throws:
      OperationCanceledException - thrown if cancellation of the stream processing was detected by this method call
      Exception - thrown if there was a processing failure

    • unwrap

      public SeqGroupProducer<T> unwrap()
      Returns the underlying SeqGroupProducer instance.
      Returns:
      the underlying SeqGroupProducer instance. This method never returns null.
